resultsMetadata.author: Stanley A <mark>Renshon</mark>
resultsMetadata.description: …The Clinton presidency is pivotal, occurring at a particularly sensitive time in American and world history. The Cold War has ended; yet Americans face daunting social and economic problems and are increasingly divided about how to address them. In this perceptive psychological portrait of Clinton and his presidency, expert Stanley <mark>Renshon</mark> investigates whether Clinton has demonstrated the requisite qualities of judgment, vision, character, and skill to meet the challenges he faces, domestically…
resultsMetadata.subtitle: Bill Clinton and the Politics of Ambition
resultsMetadata.title: High Hopes

resultsMetadata.author: Stanley A <mark>Renshon</mark>
resultsMetadata.description: … these judgments should made remains unclear. Does it matter that Gary Hart changed his name or had an affair? Should Ed Muskie's loss of composure while defending his wife during a campaign speech, or Thomas Eagleton's hospitalization for depression, have counted against them? Looking back over the past 25 years, Stanley <mark>Renshon</mark>, a political scientist and psychoanalyst, provides the first comprehensive accounting of how character has become an increasingly important issue in a presidential campaign. He traces…
resultsMetadata.title: The Psychological Assessment of Presidential Candidates
